[[Forrest City, Arkansas]], [[United States]] | death_date = Unknown | instrument = [[Human voice|Vocals]], [[guitar]] | genre = [[Country blues]], [[Memphis blues]] | occupation = [[Guitarist]], [[singing|singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = | label = [[Okeh Records|Okeh]], [[Vocalion Records|Vocalion]] | associated_acts = [[Big Walter Horton]], [[Hammie Nixon]] | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Little Buddy Doyle''' (March 20, 1911 – unknown){{cite web |url=http://spotibot.com/artist/6WesPY5lG0labyNWb0ddza |title=Little Buddy Doyle |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Spotibot.com |accessdate=July 26, 2011}} was an [[United States|American]] [[Memphis blues|Memphis]] and [[country blues]] [[guitarist]], [[singing|singer]] and [[songwriter]].{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/little-buddy-doyle-mn0003145538/credits |title=Little Buddy Doyle | Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}} He was a working associate of [[Big Walter Horton]] and [[Hammie Nixon]]. '''Charlie Doyle''' was probably born in [[Forrest City, Arkansas]], [[United States]]. During the 1930s, the diminutive Doyle performed regularly on [[Beale Street]], [[Memphis]], [[Tennessee]].{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues - From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher=Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | page= 25 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} It is generally accepted that Big Walter Horton made his first [[Sound recording and reproduction|recording]] backing Doyle, on Doyle's Memphis based eight song recordings made for the [[Okeh Records|Okeh]] and [[Vocalion Records|Vocalion]] labels in 1939.{{cite web |first= |last= |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p373/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Big Walter Horton biography by Steve Huey |publisher=Allmusic.com |accessdate=May 30, 2009}} Doyle also recorded with the [[harmonica]] player, Hammie Nixon, around the same time, although some of their recorded work remains unissued.{{cite book | first= Paul | last= Oliver | year= 2009 | title= Barrelhouse blues: location recording and the early traditions of the blues | edition= 1st | publisher= BasicCivitas Books | location= New York | isbn= 978-0-465-00881-0 | page= 140}} Most of what else is known about Doyle derives from the autobiography of [[David "Honeyboy" Edwards]], who met him and played with him. Doyle also played with [[Sunnyland Slim]]. Edwards met Doyle for the first time in [[Memphis]] in 1935. At this point Doyle usually performed in Handy Park, Memphis. Doyle was still alive and still performing in Handy Park in 1943, when Edwards again came to Memphis. In 1943, Edwards sometimes performed in Handy Park together with Doyle, Big Walter Horton and a young [[Little Walter]]. Edwards remembered Doyle clearly and he described him as a quite charismatic figure. According to Edward's description, Doyle was a red-eyed alcoholic who was drunk all the time, and had two or three gold teeth. No photos of Doyle seems to be known. Doyle was most likely called Little Buddy Doyle because of his diminutive height; according to Edward's description Doyle "... was a midget. His legs was so short that when he sat on the bench to play the guitar he couldn´t pat his feet. He had to just bump against the seat, his feet would be that far off the ground. He´d get to playing the blues and just bump, bump, bump."{{cite book | first= David Honeyboy | last= Edwards | year= 1997 | title= The World Don't Owe Me Nothing | edition= | publisher=Chicago Review Press | location= Chicago, Illinois, United States | page= 58 | isbn= 1-55652-368-8}} When Edwards met him in 1935 he was married to Hedda, who was six feet tall. According to Edwards, Hedda too was "a good guitar player in the key of G." She sometimes performed with Doyle. Little else is known of Doyle's life outside of his recorded work, and his death appears to be unrecorded. ==See also== *[[List of Memphis blues musicians]] *[[List of country blues musicians]] ==Discography== Doyle's known tracks include "Bad in Mind Blues"; "Grief Will Kill You", "Hard Scufflin' Blues", "Lost Baby Blues", "Renewed Love Blues", "She's Got Good Dry Goods", "Slick Caper Blues", "Sweet Man Blues" and "Three Sixty Nine Blues".
